subj-group.subject: Forms of Reality: The Short Story and its Moments

title-group.article-title: The "Feminine" Short Story: Recuperating the Moment

abstract.p: Despite recent critical denigrations of the representation of temporality as a defining interest in narrative, it is important to reappraise the epiphany as a feature of the short stories of "founding" modernist women writers like Virginia Woolf and Katherine Mansfield. Nevertheless, the association of the epiphanic story with "feminine" writing drove a writer like Doris Lessing to reject the epiphany as an organizing principle in her stories; she chose, instead, the more fabular, allegorical model of a writer like D. H. Lawrence. Finally, however, Lessing, like other women writers of the short story, kept in touch with the intuition of revelation in moments of being whose power act not only as organizers of narrative but also as significations of a kind of feminine sensory apprehension of temporality. This discursive implementation of the moment as the center of modernist women writers' short fiction may be recuperated so as to preserve their achievements from the preference for a decentered écriture féminine.

I am thinking here of writers like Flannery O'Connor, Joyce Carol Oates, Margaret Atwood, and Ursula Le Guin, for whom altered states of consciousness (variously defined) emphasize the fabular in the short story.
For a discussion of Lessing' s attitude towards the epiphanic moment, see Sukenick.
